Graphical abstract Cascade engineered synthesis of the drug butamben (n-butyl-p-aminobenzoate), a local anaesthetic, which is used for the treatment of chronic pain, is presented here. A new multifunctional heterogeneous catalyst was synthesized, characterized and used for the direct synthesis of n-butyl-p-aminobenzoate by hydrogenation and esterification. A mixture of p-nitrobenzoic acid, n-butanol, hydrogen, acetonitrile as solvent and catalyst was used and hydrogenated in which hydrogenation precedes esterification. A series of aluminum exchanged dodecatungstophosphoric acids (DTP) (Alx-DTP; x = 0.33–1) (5–20% w/w) supported on mesocellular foam silica (MCF) were prepared. 2% Fe loaded on 15% Al0.66DTP/MCF showed the best activity for one-pot synthesis because the metal and acid sites had proper strength and distribution on MCF. Reaction mechanism and kinetic model were developed. The catalyst 2%Fe-15% Al0.66DTP/MCF was found reusable for four catalytic cycles. This work presents an interesting case of reaction engineering using multi-functional catalyst useful in synthesis of a pharmaceutical drug butamben and has potential applications in other areas. S m Concentration of hydrogen on metal site (mol/L) CW Concentration of water molecules (mol/L) Cn Concentration of n=A,D,E,F compound in bulk (mol/L) Kn Adsorption constant of n=A,D,E,F compound in bulk (L mol−1) Ctm Total concentration of metal sites, mol/L Cta Total concentration of acid sites, mol/L k Reaction rate constant (L2 mol−1 g−1 s−1) w Catalyst loading (g/L) CA0 Initial concentration of reactant A in bulk liquid phase, mol/L 1 Introduction The drug butamben (or n-butyl-p-aminobenzoate, BAB), is a local anaesthetic, having good market, which is currently synthesized by using polluting processes. It is typically a two-step reaction leading to excessive capital and operating costs, and environmental issues. In the synthesis of BAB, two reactions are conducted sequentially, namely, esterification of p-nitrobenzoic acid with n-butanol using thionyl chloride in homogeneous system [1], followed by reduction of n-butyl-p-nitrobenzoate by using homogeneous catalysts such as Sn [2], Zn [3], Pd [4], Pt and Fe [5] in acidic medium. These processes are beset with various problems such as complex separation processes, poor atom economy and loss in selectivity of the desired product BAB, generation of huge amount of waste due to use of thionyl chloride, corrosion of reactor and accessories, etc. All methods used earlier for synthesis of BAB are tedious and hazardous. This important drug needs to be prepared by using a clean and green process, which is the topic of current work. The use of solid acids and heterogeneous hydrogenation catalysts is well known if the two steps were to be carried out separately. However, we thought of combining them as well as develop a multifunctional catalyst for a single pot (cascade engineering) synthesis to reduce waste, improve process economics and green quotient of the synthesis of BAB. The significance of one-pot or cascade engineered catalysis in the synthesis of fine chemicals and specialties have been brought out elegantly both experimentally and theoretically by us in different systems using different novel multi-functional chemical [6–13] as well as enzymatic catalysts [12,13] having tailored activities; for instance, ethyl benzyl acetoacetate and methyl isobutyl ketone (MIBK) [6], γ-valerolactone, 1,4-pentanediol and 2-methyltetrahydrofuran [7], γ-butyrolactone [9], n-butanal and 2-methyl-1-pentanol [8], p-hydroxybenzaldehyde [10], 3-phenyl propyl benzoate [11], (R)-phenyl ethyl acetate [12], and (R)-1-(pyridin-4-yl)ethyl acetate [13]. Various industrially significant reactions are carried out using solid acid catalysts such as ion exchange resins, zeolites, mesoporous aluminosilicates, acidic clays, pillared clays, supported heteropolyacids (HPA) and sulfated zirconia [14–16]. Keggin-type heteropolyacids (HPAs) possess unique acid and redox properties, which make them valuable in various acid catalyzed reactions. Strong acidic nature of HPAs tends to show high catalytic activity. Among all HPAs, dodecatungstophosphoric acid (DTP) is more frequently used as acid catalyst which is highly stable possessing Bronsted acid sites. The major disadvantages of using bulk HPAs are as follows: catalyst separation due to nano size, low surface area of ∼ 1–10 m2/g, poor stability and reusability. Thus, immobilizing HPAs on various supports such as zeolite [17,18], activated carbon [19–23], zirconia [24–26], mesoporous silica [27–30], titania [31,32], alumina [33], SBA-15 [34] and clays [35] helps to increase the surface area that increases accessibility of acid sites to render highly active catalysts and environment friendly processes. Mesocellularfoam silica (MCF) is used as a catalyst support due to its large surface area and favorable pore size that has proved to be the most promising among other supports. It has the ultra-cage 3D structure with uniform spherical cells (1550 nm) having a large window (520 nm) and thus favors rapid diffusion of reacting species [36]. Mesoporous silica-supported HPAs have shown high catalytic activity as compared to the parent HPAs, and are easily separable and recyclable [37]. Dodecatungstophosphoric acid, H3PW12O40 (DTP), is one of the most studied HPAs in both supported and unsupported form. Metal ions such as Na+, Al3+, Cu2+, Cs+, Ag+, Y3+, Fe3+, Bi3+, Ru3+, Al3+, Sm3+, Ti4+, Zr4+, Hf4+ and Sn4+ have been widely studied to make the cation exchanged HPAs that accept electron pair generating Lewis acid sites. As compared to DTP, Cs2.5H0.5PW12O40 (Cs-DTP) and its supported forms have been widely studied in various reactions due to high thermal stability and acidity. Cs-DTP/K-10 clay has been reported in several reactions [35,38,39]. The activity of aluminum exchanged DTP supported on montmorillonite K-10 clay with varying Al content was thoroughly studied in benzoylation of diphenyl oxide with benzoyl anhydride for which Al0.66-DTP/K-10 was the most active and robust catalyst [40]. Therefore, in this work synergistic effect of mesoporous support and Al content in DTP was systematically studied, and was converted into a bifunctional catalyst by using a suitable metal. Hydrogenation normally makes use of noble metal catalysts prepared from Pt, Pd, Rh and Ir. Reduction of p-nitrobenzoic acid to p-aminobenzoic acid mainly involves application of homogeneous catalysts. A few heterogeneous catalysts reported earlier for this reaction are: 10 wt. % Pd/C [41], Ni/SiO2 with hydrazine hydrate [42], and Sn in the presence of ammonium bromide [43]. Aromatic nitro compounds are also reduced by: (a) SnCl2, 2H2O in alcohol or ethyl acetate or by anhydrous SnCl2 [44], (b) Cu–Ni/MWCNT and Cu–Ru/MWCNT with NaBH4 [45], (c) Al-NiCl2·6H2O-THF [46], and (d) Pd/C [47]. Iron based catalysts are less toxic, economical and environmentally benign. Gieshoff et al. [48] reported hydrogenation of olefin at 1 bar H2 pressure using FeCl3/LiAlH4. Viacheslav et al. [49] observed the highest catalytic activity for Fe/MCF-17 in the hydrogenation of CO among all other Fe based catalysts. Some other Fe based catalysts are as follows: Fe/C for selective reduction of nitrate in water [50], Fe/ZrO2 for hydrogenation of CO [51], and Pd-Fe/SiO2 for hydrogenation of 2,4-dinitrotoluene [52]. Butamben (n-butyl-p-aminobenzoate) is similar to benzocaine, which is an ethyl ester of p-aminobenzoic acid that is used in ointments for skin pain and itching treatment [53]. It controls localized pain for long periods of time when used in drug delivery systems. Butamben (BAB) is a poorly soluble drug that doesn’t require excipients with slow and long term release. It is given as an epidural formulation for treatment of chronic pain such as the intractable pain associated with advanced stages of cancer. Anaesthesia in adjacent spinal segments is not detected while using BAB formulations in chronic pain treatment which proves that epidural administration results in selective sensory effects [53,54]. BAB is synthesized by two different routes: (i) esterification of p-nitrobenzoic acid with n-butanol, (ii) hydrogenation of n-butyl-p-nitrobenzoate. Morogina et al. [4] reported liquid-phase hydrogenation of p-nitrobenzoic acid esters on conventional heterogeneous Pd/C and Pd/Al2O3, and polymeric AV-17-8-Pd and AN-1-Pd catalysts. The maximum rate of the hydrogenation reaction was observed in methanol at 55 °C and pressure of 1 atm [4]. There are no reports available on esterification of p-nitrobenzoic acid with n-butanol using a heterogeneous catalyst. Hosangadi and Dave [1] have studied the same esterification reaction in the presence of thionyl chloride that resulted in the corresponding ester. Thus a green approach for preparing n-butyl-p-aminobenzoate was needed by developing a multifunctional heterogeneous catalyst. In the present work, we have systematically synthesized 2% Fe-AlxDTP/MCF catalysts with varying aluminum content (x = 0.33–1) in DTP (5–20% w/w) supported on MCF. Catalytic activity of these catalysts was investigated in the selective one-pot synthesis of n-butyl-p-aminobenzoate from p-nitrobenzoic acid by a greener approach. All the catalysts were characterized by different methods. The best catalyst was characterized after reuse to ascertain its fidelity. Mechanism and kinetics were derived on the basis of a systematic study of different parameters. We report here that the one-pot or cascade engineered synthesis of BAB leads to a process which is efficient with regard to material and energy, and gives much higher yields and selectivity in comparison with previously reported literature. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Tetraethoxysilane (TEOS) and pluronic P-123 (M. W. 5800) were procured from Sigma Aldrich (USA). 35% Aqueous HCl, methanol, mesitylene, ammonium fluoride, dodecatungstophosphoric acid hexahydrate, acetonitrile and p-nitrobenzoic acid were obtained from S.D. Fine Chem. Ltd, Mumbai, India. Ferric chloride hexahydrate and aluminum chloride were procured from Thomas Baker Pvt Ltd, Mumbai. n-Butanol was procured from AVRA Synthesis, Hyderabad, India. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 General procedure for synthesis of mesocellular foam silica (MCF) MCF was prepared by a procedure reported in the literature [30]. Details are provided in the Electronic Supplementary Information (ESI). 2.2.2 Synthesis of (5–20% w/w) AlxDTP/MCF (5–20% w/w) AlxDTP/MCF catalysts with varying aluminum content (x = 0.33–1) were synthesized by incipient wetness impregnation method. Two steps were involved. Firstly 4 g of MCF was dried in oven at 120 °C. Aluminum nitrate hexahydrate (0.06 g) was dissolved in 5 ml methanol and added in small portions as an aluminum source to MCF. The solid was dried at 120 °C for 4 h. In the second step, 0.71 g of DTP was dissolved in methanol and added in small intervals to Al/MCF which was dried after every addition to avoid slurry formation to get dry solid material. The resultant material was dried in oven at 120 °C for 12 h. It was further calcined at 300 °C for 4 h to get 15% w/w AlxDTP/MCF. Other AlxDTP/MCF catalysts were synthesized in a similar manner where x (number of aluminum ions) was varied from 0.33 to 1.5–in 20% (w/w). 2.2.3 Synthesis of 2 wt % Fe –15% w/w Al0.66DTP/MCF 2 wt % Fe-Al0.66DTP/MCF was prepared by impregnation method. 4 g Al0.66DTP/MCF was dried in oven. 0.38 g FeCl3 hexahydrate was dissolved in methanol and then added in small amount to 15% w/w Al0.66DTP/MCF. The resultant solid was dried in oven at 120 °C for 6 h. Further it was reduced by hydrogen pressure of 15 atm at 200 °C for 6 h. 2.3 Reaction setup Experiments were carried out in a 100 ml batch autoclave reactor of Amar Equipments, Mumbai. In a standard procedure, 0.005 mol p-nitrobenzoic acid, 0.15 mol n-butanol and 0.025 g catalyst with acetonitrile as solvent (total volume 50 ml) were used and the reaction was carried out at 150 °C with an agitation speed of 1000 rpm at 15 atm hydrogen pressure. An initial sample was collected when the desired temperature was reached. It was stirred at a given speed and samples withdrawn at regular intervals of time for HPLC analysis. Product confirmation was done on HR-MS (see ESI). The crude product was obtained by evaporating the solvent. This was then purified by column chromatography on silica gel using a mixture of heptane and ethyl acetate as the eluent. Further it was analyzed by 1H and 13C NMR (see ESI). 2.4 Analysis method The analysis was carried out using HPLC (Agilent 1200 Infinity series) using Agilent C18 reverse phase column (250 mm 4.6 mm, 5 μm), UV detector at a wavelength 280 nm with injection volume 10 μl, phase flow rate 1.0 ml min−1. The column temperature was maintained at 25 °C. 0.1% Acetic acid: acetonitrile with a ratio of 80:20 was used as the mobile phase. Under the chromatographic conditions, the analytes were eluted within 20 min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Catalysts were characterized by sophisticated techniques (ESI). Details of TG-DSC (Fig. S1), XPS (Fig. S2), FT-IR (Fig. S3), and SEM/EDXS (Figs. S6 and S7) are provided in ESI. 3.1.1 XRD Wide-angle XRD patterns of MCF support and catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . Broad XRD peaks were observed in the 2θ range of 20–25° that correspond to mesoporous nature [30]. All catalysts show a similar diffraction pattern which confirms the proper distribution of 2% Fe-Al0.66DTP on MCF support. 3.1.2 TPD analysis The acidic strength of all prepared catalysts was measured by using ammonia–TPD method (Fig. 2 ). A distinct peak was observed in the temperature range of 100–300 °C, which confirmed the presence of strong acidic sites. The loading of Al0.66DTP on MCF support increases its acid strength. Further impregnation of Fe resulted in a slight decrease of acid sites which confirmed the presence of Fe within the pores of MCF. The TPR analysis of 2%Fe-AlDTP/MCF shows the presence of metal sites with 2.9 mmol/g-cat hydrogen adsorbed up to 700 °C (Fig. S4). 3.1.3 Textural characteristics Nitrogen adsorption-desorption method was used to evaluate the surface properties of the prepared catalysts (Table 1 ). At high relative pressure, all the catalysts showed type IV and H1-type hysteresis loops which confirmed the mesoporous nature with the large pore size of MCF support (ESI) (Fig. S5) [25,30]. 3.1.4 TEM images TEM images of 2%Fe-15%w/wAl0.66DTP/MCF at different magnifications with SAED pattern are shown in Fig. 3 . The particle size of 2% Fe-Al0.66DTP was found to be in the range of 2–3.5 nm. Moreover, 2% Fe-Al0.66DTP particles appeared in an agglomerated form when impregnated on the mesoporous support. 3.2 Efficacy of the prepared catalysts Various catalyst like Pd-CsDTP/K-10, Pd/ZrO2, Pd/K-10, 5%Pd/C and Fe-AlDTP/MCF were used to study and compare their catalytic activity (Fig. 4 ). The highest activity was observed for 2% Fe-15% w/w Al0.66DTP/MCF as it possesses high surface area, uniform distribution of metal-acid sites, and ease of accessibility of the active sites to the reacting molecules. The aluminum exchanged catalysts are highly acidic as compared to other catalysts [30]. Effect of moles of aluminum was studied ranging from 0.33 to 1 2%Fe-AlxDTP/MCF (Fig. S8). With the increase in moles of aluminium, there was an increase in the concentration of Lewis acidic sites which enhanced the acidity of the catalyst. There was a slight difference in conversion of reaction with 1 and 0.66 mol of Al. Hence all further experiments were carried out with 2%Fe-Al0.66DTP/MCF. The conversion of p-nitrobenzoic acid for each catalyst was calculated to observe that 2% Fe-15% (w/w) Al0.66DTP/MCF resulted in 100% conversion of p-nitrobenzoic acid with high selectivity (95%) for n-butyl-p-aminobenzoate. By fixing 2% Fe, the effect of loading of Al0.66DTP was studied from 5 to 20% w/w on MCF (Fig. S9) which showed that with an increase in loading there was a substantial increase in conversion and selectivity. 15% w/w loading was the best and used for further studies as there was no change in conversion and selectivity for 20% w/w. The effect of speed of agitation was studied (ESI) (Fig. S10) and theoretical calculations were also performed to ascertain that indeed it was the case. For the sake of brevity these are not shown here but are available in some of our earlier publications [55,56]. 3.2.1 Effect of catalyst loading The quantity of catalyst was varied from 0.001 to 0.0075 g/cm3 (Fig. 5 ). As the catalyst quantity was increased, more number of active metal and acid catalytic sites were available for reaction to occur which led to a significant increase in initial reaction rate. There was no significant change in conversion after 0.005 g/cm3 of catalyst loading. Hence catalyst quantity of 0.005 g/cm3 was chosen for the next experiments. Initial reaction rates were plotted against catalyst loading which were linear proving that the rate is proportional to the number of active catalytic site (Fig. 6 ). The effect of concentration of the reactants was also studied (Fig. S11). 3.2.2 Effect of hydrogen pressure To analyze the effect of hydrogen pressure on the conversion of p-nitrobenzoic acid, reactions were carried out with varying hydrogen pressure from 0.5 to 2 MPa (Fig. 7 ). As the hydrogen pressure was increased, there was a significant increase in conversion. A linear relationship was observed for the initial rate of reaction against hydrogen pressure (Fig. 8 ). The reaction rate and conversions were the similar beyond 1.5 MPa demonstrating that it is independent of partial pressure which can be explained on the basis of LHHW model. Hence, 1.5 MPa hydrogen pressure was selected for the next studies. 3.2.3 Effect of temperature Effect of temperature on conversion of p-nitrobenzoic acid was studied from 393 K to 423 K by keeping all other reaction parameters constant (Fig. 9 ). As temperature increased, there was an increase in the initial rate and conversion of p-nitrobenzoic acid. At 423 K, conversion of p-nitrobenzoic acid is 100% and further conversion of intermediates takes place to selectively form n-butyl-p-aminobenzoate. After 423 K there was no significant increase in p-nitrobenzoic acid conversion. The rate of formation of p-aminobenzoic acid increases with temperature rise up to 423 K. Hence, 423 K was selected as the optimum temperature. Catalyst Reusability was conducted and included in ESI (Fig. S12). 3.3 Reaction mechanism and kinetic model The sequential reactions to yield n-butyl-p-aminobenzoate from p-nitrobenzoic acid are shown in Scheme 1 . p-Nitrobenzoic acid undergoes hydrogenation to p-aminobenzoic acid followed by esterification with n-butanol to form n-butyl-p-aminobenzoate. The possible path is the formation of p-aminobenzoic acid by hydrogenation of p-nitrobenzoic acid and its further esterification with n-butanol to n-butyl-p-aminobenzoate. Formation of intermediates (B) and (C) was not observed (HPLC analysis) due to the fast steps which further form p-aminobenzoic acid (D) that reacts with butanol to give product (F) as implied from the concentration profiles with time for reactant (p-nitrobenzoic acid), hydrogenated product (p-aminobenzoic acid) and esterified product (n-butyl-p-aminobenzoate) (Fig. S13). In these consecutive steps, the first step of hydrogenation of p-nitrobenzoic acid is the rate determining step as all steps are considered fast. The mechanism of one-pot reaction by using 2% Fe-15% (w/w) Al0.66DTP/ MCF on catalyst surface is shown in Scheme 2 . Langmuir-Hinshelwood-Hougen-Watson (LHHW) mechanism was used to develop a kinetic model (See ESI). Individual rate constants were evaluated at different temperatures and activation energy values were calculated. To validate the proposed model, experimental results at optimized conditions were used. The rate constants were obtained using Polymath 6.0 Software. Calculated rate constants were plotted against catalyst loading to obtain intrinsic kinetic constant (Fig. S14). The Arrhenius plots were drawn for the three steps to calculate activation energy values (Fig. 10 ) (Table S1). According to the parity plot, theoretical and experimental values for the rate of reaction match well (Fig. S15). Hence it validates the model (Table 2 ). 4 Conclusions 2% Fe-Al0.66DTP (15%w/w)/MCF was the best multi-functional catalyst for the synthesis of butamben (n-butyl-p-aminobenzoate) by hydrogenation and esterification in one pot reaction. Conversion of p-nitrobenzoic acid of 100% was achieved with 95% selectivity to butamben at 1:30 mol ratio in acetonitrile with 0.005 g/cm3 catalyst loading at 1.5 MPa hydrogen pressure at 423 K in 6 h. The catalyst was active, selective and reusable for 5 runs. Reaction mechanism and kinetics were also studied which will be helpful for scale-up. Overall the process is clean and green. coredata.dc:description: Cascade engineered synthesis of the drug butamben (n-butyl-p-aminobenzoate), a local anaesthetic, which is used for the treatment of chronic pain, is presented here. A new multifunctional heterogeneous catalyst was synthesized, characterized and used for the direct synthesis of n-butyl-p-aminobenzoate by hydrogenation and esterification. A mixture of p-nitrobenzoic acid, n-butanol, hydrogen, acetonitrile as solvent and catalyst was used and hydrogenated in which hydrogenation precedes esterification. A series of aluminum exchanged dodecatungstophosphoric acids (DTP) (Alx-DTP; x = 0.33–1) (5–20% w/w) supported on mesocellular foam silica (MCF) were prepared. 2% Fe loaded on 15% Al0.66DTP/MCF showed the best activity for one-pot synthesis because the metal and acid sites had proper strength and distribution on MCF. Reaction mechanism and kinetic model were developed. The catalyst 2%Fe-15% Al0.66DTP/MCF was found reusable for four catalytic cycles. This work presents an interesting case of reaction engineering using multi-functional catalyst useful in synthesis of a pharmaceutical drug butamben and has potential applications in other areas.
coredata.dc:title: Multi-functional Fe-Al0.66DTP/MCF catalyst in cascade engineered synthesis of the drug butamben: Novelty of catalyst, reaction kinetics and mechanism
